headline: Ruben Amorim immediately admitted 'mistake' before making decision on Man Utd job
body: Months before taking over at Manchester United, Ruben Amorim held talks with another Premier League club. However, he quickly recognised it was a mistake for him to speak to West Ham about succeeding David Moyes while he was still in the midst of a title race with Sporting CP.

"So let's get the elephant out of the room and I'll talk about it once," Amorim said in April 2024 when discussing the West Ham talks. "The first thing is to say that the club was aware of my trip. It's important and changes the context.

"Then, talk about the cloak of secrecy that surrounded the trip. I secretly parked the car outside, secretly walked past 15 people, past people and took photographs and got on a plane to take away a little bit of this thing that was all done behind the club's back, that didn't happen.

"Obviously my trip was a mistake, the timing was completely wrong, it didn't seem right at the time. It was wrong, especially when I'm so demanding with my players and always the first to say that each one's problems don't go away. They can overpower the team, I have already removed players from the squad for much less. It was my mistake, I have to accept it and live with it."

Amorim's first season in charge at United saw them limp to a lowly bottom-half finish, their worst in the Premier League era, with defeat in the Europa League final ensuring they would have no European football for the first time in more than a decade. Results have improved slightly this term, but not enough for the board to keep him in charge.

"With Manchester United sitting sixth in the Premier League, the club’s leadership has reluctantly made the decision that it is the right time to make a change," the club said in a statement on Monday morning. "This will give the team the best opportunity of the highest possible Premier League finish."

Since Amorim held talks with West Ham, the London side have cycled through several permanent managers of their own. Moyes was given the remainder of the 2023/24 season before being replaced by Julen Lopetegui, who only lasted half a season himself before making way for Graham Potter in January 2025.

Potter was still in the dugout at the start of this season but got his marching orders in September, with Nuno Espirito Santo taking over. And now, with the Hammers four points from Premier League safety, there has been speculation over Nuno's future at the London Stadium.

headline: Man Utd had no choice but to sack Ruben Amorim - they should have done it sooner
body: Ruben Amorim was lucky to get as long as he did. Fourteen months at Old Trafford has brought just 25 wins in Amorim’s 63 games in charge and the worst win ratio of 32 per cent of any Manchester United manager in the Premier League era.

Where is the team going? What is the team’s identity? You look at the table and you could argue that Amorim has made progress and is pushing for Europe. But that is when you need to check yourself and remember this is Manchester United we are talking about.

This is the club which sees it itself as the biggest club in the world with the biggest ambitions and an incredible global fanbase which is absolutely second to none when it comes to backing their managers.
And even the most loyal United supporters had become split on Amorim. United should not be languishing in sixth place after 20 very unconvincing games this season.
The club backed the manager to the hilt in the summer. They spent £216m on new signings over the summer with Bryan Mbeumo, Benjamin Sesko, Matheus Cunha and Senne Lammens all arriving.
United were absolutely right to stick with Amorim into this campaign and give him every chance to succeed because he took over mid-season and inherited a bit of a mess from Erik ten Hag.
But a really top manager would be able to take the squad and turn them into a team fit to wear the shirt.
Do you really think a manager of the class and pedigree of Pep Guardiola would be struggling in his second season? He would build a team which, even if it was not winning, would be competitive.

Look at the job even Enzo Maresca did at Chelsea. He won trophies and got them into the Champions League places. Oliver Glasner is in the bookies’ list of favourites for United because of the job he has done at Crystal Palace. They won a trophy.
All of those managers would unquestionably be doing better at United with the same players that Amorim has at his disposal. They would not be throwing away games and leads.
Amorim was crazy to challenge the board in a power grab when actually he was doing a pretty average job. He needed their backing - not to spark a civil war.
You also have to question him on specific players. You could make a case that Kobbie Mainoo was almost promoted too soon as he found himself in the heart of England’s midfield in the Euros.
But Mainoo still showed that he is one of England’s brightest young stars. And the way he has been discarded and overlooked is a failure on Amorim’s part - not the player’s.
Similar with Benjamin Sesko. He looks utterly broken. This is a serious player who has got potential and would be better in a better team with a better manager.
When United signed Sesko, Cunha and Mbeumo in the summer, that should have been a front three to compete with the best in the Premier League. Then Bruno Fernandes also in the supply line.

Instead, we get Amorim hardly ever using them together because he was so wedded to his tactics and formation. He left it too late to change. That is not being strong as a manager. It is a weakness to be so inflexible.
It is all well and good to talk about other managers getting time. Mikel Arteta is a prime example. But Arsenal is different to Manchester United. Do you really think United can wait two years?
Of course not. Even Sir Jim Ratcliffe misjudged that one when he said Amorim would get time. To get time, you have to show progress.
And, ultimately, Amorim was not doing nearly enough to warrant more time. It is painful, brutal and looks chaotic. But United had to take the decision to sack him.

headline: Man Utd bosses broke promise to Ruben Amorim as true reason for sacking emerges
body: Ruben Amorim has been sacked as Manchester United manager just three months after owner Sir Jim Ratcliffe said he needed "over three years" in the hot seat before he could be judged. Amorim has lasted 14 months as United boss after he was dismissed on Monday morning following a remarkable press conference rant.

Former midfielder and under-18s boss Darren Fletcher has been promoted to become the interim manager ahead of the Premier League game against Burnley on Wednesday. Amorim departs with a record of just 24 wins from his 63 matches in charge.

Yet despite overseeing a 15th-place finish in the league last season, defeat in the Europa League final to Tottenham which deprived the club of European football and an embarrassing loss against Grimsby in the Carabao Cup, Amorim retained the backing of Ratcliffe in October.

"He has not had the best of seasons," the 30 per cent shareholder and controller of football decisions at United said on the Times' The Business podcast. "Ruben needs to demonstrate he is a great coach over three years. That's where I would be."

He added: "The press, sometimes I don't understand. They want overnight success. They think it's a light switch. You know, you flick a switch and it's all going to be roses tomorrow. You can't run a club like Manchester United on knee-jerk reactions to some journalist who goes off on one every week."

Tensions have been bubbling barely beneath the surface at United in recent weeks, with Amorim frustrated by his threadbare squad. Injuries to Bruno Fernandes, Mason Mount, Kobbie Mainoo, Harry Maguire and Matthijs de Ligt, as well as the absences of Bryan Mbeumo, Amad and Noussair Mazraoui at the Africa Cup of Nations, has left a seriously depleted squad.

Things came to a head at Elland Road when Amorim responded angrily to a question about whether he retained the support of the board. "Guys, to stop with that, and I noticed that you received selective information about everything. I came here to be the manager of Manchester United, not to be the coach of Manchester United. That is clear," he said.

"I know that my name is not Tuchel, is not Conte, is not Mourinho, but I'm the manager of Manchester United. It's going to be like this for 18 months or when the board decided to change. That was my point. I want to finish with that. I'm not going to quit. I will do my job until other guy is coming here to replace me.
"I just want to say that I'm going to be the manager of this team, not just the coach. I was really clear on that. That is going to finish in 18 months, and then everyone is going to move on."
That rant ultimately caused his downfall and United will now begin the search for a new manager as they try to salvage another season.

headline: Paul Scholes proven right as Ruben Amorim record before Man Utd sack says it all
body: Paul Scholes previously said Ruben Amorim did not understand Manchester United - and judging by the Portuguese coach's record at the club, the ex-Old Trafford midfielder was correct.

Amorim, 40, was given his marching orders by United less than 24 hours after he lashed out at the likes of Gary Neville and other figures at the club in a "bizarre" press conference which ended with him storming out. United finished 15th at the end of last season, but Amorim was given his P45 when the club were in sixth place, just three points away from the top four.

A flat 1-1 away draw with Leeds United proved to be Amorim's final game in charge, which is fitting given Scholes' previous criticism of the ex-United head coach. Moreover, Amorim's record, when stacked up against his predecessors, also support Scholes' comments.

On the Good, the Bad and the Football Podcast, Scholes, while talking to ex-United team-mate Nicky Butt, said: "I don't think this manager gets this club full stop. I just don't think he's the right man.

"Man United is about risk & entertainment, more than anything, at home especially. Having fans on the edge of their seat, ready to go, wingers who beat people, shots on goal, bits of skills. There’s nothing there."
Amorim departs with a miserable record at United. While he did guide them to the Europa League final, he also walks away with lowest win-rate of any United manager in the Premier League.

He only won 31.9% of his matches, winning 15, drawing 13 and losing 19. The next worst United boss was interim manager Ralf Rangnick, who only emerged victorious in 41.7% of his matches, winning 10, drawing seven and losing seven.

Erik ten Hag, the man Amorim replaced at Old Trafford, won a lot more matches, registering 44 victories, 14 draws and 27 losses, a win rate of 51.8%. When it comes to the number of goals scored per-game, only Rangnick did worse than Amorim's record of 66 goals in 47 matches, equivalent to a goals per game ratio of 1.40, just 0.02 more than Rangnick's 1.38.

While Scholes was scathing towards Amorim, he also hit out at the United board for deciding to appoint him in the first place. He said: "We talk about this as a different club. They’ve got Omar Berrada, they’ve got Jason Wilcox, who are probably brilliant at their job, brilliant at what they do.

"They’re not Man Utd, they don’t have a clue what it’s like to buy a Manchester United player, to bring a Manchester United manager in. If you went to Sporting Lisbon and watched them, they play three at the back, right away that’s a no.

"Man Utd never do that. They can’t do that. It’s been proven over years, and years, and years and I’m talking before Sir Alex Ferguson, it was always about 4-4-1-1 or 4-4-2 and entertaining people. He hasn’t got that in him.
"He brought four defenders on against West Ham. If we go 1-0 up, the manager (Ferguson) always said, ‘Two, three, four.’ I think we were playing Chelsea, we went 1-0 up and we sat back a little bit.
"Now Chelsea were a good team. But the manager went absolutely nuts after the game. ‘That doesn’t happen here. When you score one, you go for two, you go for the throat every single time.’"

headline: Sir Alex Ferguson made Ruben Amorim and transfers verdict clear for Man Utd chiefs
body: Sir Alex Ferguson had expressed his support for Ruben Amorim's transfer dealings at Manchester United. The Red Devils announced on Monday that Amorim had been sacked as head coach.

Amorim, who joined United from Sporting CP in November 2024, was vocal about his role within the club following his team's draw with Leeds on Sunday. He stated: "I came here to be the manager of Manchester United, not to be the coach of Manchester United. And that is clear.
"I know that my name is not Tuchel, it's not Conte, it's not Mourinho, but I'm the manager of Manchester United. And it's going to be like this for 18 months, or when the board decides to change."

Amorim voiced his concerns publicly with the January transfer window open, suggesting frustration with their recruitment. However, legendary United boss Sir Alex Ferguson had previously endorsed the club's summer signings, including praising the impact of goalkeeper Senne Lammens since his arrival at Old Trafford.

"There are signs, the manager has had some good signs," Ferguson told Raceday RTV in November. "Particularly the goalkeeper has been outstanding, he's only played three or four games and he's looking really good.

"Of course, Mbeumo and Cunha, the new players from Wolves and Brentford, they've added to it. I hope the manager gets a bit of success because at United you need to have success - the signs are getting better.
"I think back-to-back wins is something teams like United should always expect. But having gone through a cycle where the improvement has to come by waiting and being patient, they'll enjoy it now."
While Ferguson did not mention new striker Benjamin Sesko, the 84-year-old appears impressed with the club's other key signings. He repeated his admiration for Lammens, Cunha and Mbeumo last month.
"I think the appointment of the goalkeeper has made a difference," Ferguson told Press Box PR. "He's young at 23, he's quick, a big lad, good feet and hands, and I think that helps.

"I think they have needed that player. United have always had inspirational players over the years. I think that has helped. The other two, Mbeumo and Cunha, they look as if they will contribute to the recovery of our form."

United are currently sixth in the table, matching Chelsea on points and trailing fourth-placed Liverpool by three. However, Ferguson has previously argued that there is no instant solution to turn United back into title contenders.

"He (Amorim) is a good personality, it is not easy," Ferguson said to Press Box PR. "I remember looking back on my own time there, starting off when Liverpool were the bee's knees. They were a fantastic club winning the European Cup four times and all that, but then it took them 31 years to win the league again.

"We are now in the same situation. It could be 10 years, could be 11 years, because of that cycle. It has to be thought out carefully and we have to make sure the recruitment is going to be better than what it was."

headline: Gareth Southgate has 'laid out two demands' to replace Ruben Amorim at Man Utd
body: Manchester United were reportedly told that Gareth Southgate would demand time and patience from them if he were to succeed Ruben Amorim. The Red Devils will be looking for their seventh permanent manager since Sir Alex Ferguson retired in 2013 after dismissing Amorim on Monday.

Amorim's future as United boss was thrown into doubt after Sunday's 1-1 draw at Leeds - with the Portuguese suggesting that he might leave when his contract ends in 18 months. The ex-Sporting man insisted on being recognised as the manager at Old Trafford - rather than the head coach - despite the latter being his official title since his appointment by Ineos in November 2024.

Now, Ineos have decided to end the Amorim project - sacking him after a 14-month tenure at M16. The club issued a statement confirming his dismissal, expressing hope that their change will boost their performance in the Premier League this season with European football still a clear possibility, once again.

And it was reported in October last year - when Amorim was still in charge - former England manager Southgate was debating whether to throw his hat in the ring for the managerial position at Old Trafford.

However, it was suggested Southgate would hold reservations about taking up the job and would demand four years to turn the tide, which the board may not be willing to give him, or anyone. As per The Sun, sources suggested that the boyhood United fan would need assurance that the top brass would stick to any longer-term goals planned.

The publication also claimed that Southgate harbours concerns that the board would demand instant success from him, while he takes an approach centred around gradual success over a prolonged period. The 55-year-old has been out of work since stepping down as England manager after guiding the Three Lions to a runners-up place at Euro 2024 - losing 2-1 to Spain in the final.

Southgate is not the only manager who has been linked with succeeding Amorim. Palace's boss Oliver Glasner and Brighton's Fabian Hurzeler have been rumoured as favourites to make the move to Old Trafford. Real Madrid legend Zinedine Zidane and Barcelona icon Xavi Hernandez have also seen their names tossed into the mix.

Announcing Amorim's departure in a statement on Monday, United said: "Ruben Amorim has departed his role as head coach of Manchester United. Ruben was appointed in November 2024 and he led the team to a UEFA Europa League Final in Bilbao in May.

"With Manchester United sitting sixth in the Premier League, the club's leadership has reluctantly made the decision that it's the right time to make a change. This will give the team the best opportunity of the highest possible Premier League finish.
"The club would like to thank Ruben for his contribution to the club and wishes him well for the future.
"Darren Fletcher will take charge of the team against Burnley on Wednesday."

headline: Ex-Man Utd stars' WhatsApp messages to Darren Fletcher revealed after Ruben Amorim sacked
body: Former Manchester United defender Rio Ferdinand has revealed that the WhatsApp group featuring ex-Reds legends is lively with messages of congratulations and good luck to Darren Fletcher following news of Ruben Amorim's dismissal. His former teammate is set to step into the caretaker role, with his debut match against Burnley approaching this week.

Amorim presided over United's most dismal Premier League campaign in the club's top-flight history, whilst his team suffered defeat to Tottenham Hotspur in the Europa League final. The Portuguese manager had witnessed an improvement in results this term, accumulating 31 points from 20 fixtures.
Nevertheless, consecutive stalemates against relegation-threatened Wolves and Leeds United prompted Amorim to deliver a shocking statement during his final media appearance as United chief.
The Portuguese tactician launched a scathing attack on United's boardroom figures, with his fractured relationship with Jason Wilcox becoming public knowledge.

On his Rio Ferdinand Presents podcast, the former United centre-back revealed: "I'm really excited to see him, I mean the Man United [ex-players] WhatsApp group is popping off as you can imagine with congratulations and good luck messages to Fletch.
Man Utd sack Ruben Amorim LIVE: Statement in full, next manager decision confirmed
"I think he'll be ejecting himself [from the group], or won't be answering. Let me just check and see if he's answered already because he ain't been as active since he's been the Under-18s manager.

"Let me just see. Fletch, where are you? Nope. You've got Youngy, Edwin van der Sar, Anders Lindergaard and myself all wishing him good luck. I think [the good luck messages] will be coming in more and more over the next couple of minutes.
"I wish him well. Darren Fletcher, he's had some big, big moments in his career and he's also had some turmoil in his life with his health.

"He [has] a wonderful family, he's the right kind of person that you'd want to get a chance and I just hope he goes in there and does himself justice because this is a wonderful opportunity that anyone on this planet - especially someone who's connected to the club - would give their right arm for, to have this opportunity. I'm sure he'll give it all he's got.

"One thing we will do is he'll take counsel. He'll lean on people. I'm sure one of his first phone calls will be Sir Alex Ferguson - followed by myself hahaha. But he will ask those questions. He's got humility.

"If I was a betting man, I'd say he'll do a good enough job. I want him to make it difficult for the hierarchy to make a decision on the next manager - on the next coach. Because that's obviously the question everyone's asking."
Amorim departs United having secured merely 24 victories from 63 matches, marking the poorest record of any manager since Sir Alex Ferguson stepped down from the role.

The choice to part ways with Amorim was made by United's senior management, which includes Wilcox and chief executive Omar Berrada. A United statement read: "Ruben Amorim has departed his role as Head Coach of Manchester United. Ruben was appointed in November 2024 and led the team to a UEFA Europa League Final in Bilbao in May.

"With Manchester United sitting sixth in the Premier League, the club's leadership has reluctantly made the decision that it is the right time to make a change. This will give the team the best opportunity of the highest possible Premier League finish.
"The club would like to thank Ruben for his contribution to the club and wishes him well for the future. Darren Fletcher will take charge of the team against Burnley on Wednesday."

headline: Man Utd: Sir Jim Ratcliffe made thoughts clear on manager he admires after Ruben Amorim sack
body: Following the sacking of Ruben Amorim, Sir Jim Ratcliffe has a massive decision to make. There have been glimpses of encouragement from Manchester United this season, but a run of underwhelming performances and results - coupled with a breakdown in the relationship between manager and owners - has resulted Amorim being relieved of his duties after only 14 months at the helm.

Focus has already shifted to who will replace the 40-year-old. United are unlikely to struggle for interest in the vacancy, but one name Ratcliffe has openly admired in the past could be extremely difficult to lure.

That man is Jurgen Klopp, who famously guided Liverpool to Premier League and Champions League glory. Ratcliffe has spoken glowingly about the German in the past,- suggesting that Klopp would represent something of a dream appointment.

"Klopp has this ability to drive his players to a frenzy," he said back in March 2024, shortly after taking over footballing operations at Old Trafford. "Total commitment on the pitch. And, you know, that's one of the things a good coach can do."
Klopp is now working as Head of Global Soccer at Red Bull, a role he accepted soon after stepping away from Liverpool at the conclusion of the 2023/24 season.

He has made it clear before that his spell at Anfield would be his final job in management. When that stance is combined with the bitter rivalry between Liverpool and United, a switch to Old Trafford looks highly improbable.

As a result, United are expected to pursue alternative and more attainable options. Crystal Palace manager Oliver Glasner is believed to be high on the shortlist, while former England boss Gareth Southgate - another long-time favourite of Ratcliffe - is also under consideration.

Bournemouth head coach Andoni Iraola, Aston Villa's Unai Emery and ex-United defender Laurent Blanc have also been mentioned as possibilities. In the short term, however, U-18s coach Darren Fletcher has been placed in temporary charge until a permanent appointment is made.
United announced Amorim's exit in a statement released on Monday morning. "Ruben Amorim has departed his role as Head Coach of Manchester United," the statement read.

"Ruben was appointed in November 2024 and led the team to a UEFA Europa League Final in Bilbao in May. With Manchester United sitting sixth in the Premier League, the club's leadership has reluctantly made the decision that it is the right time to make a change.

"This will give the team the best opportunity of the highest possible Premier League finish. The club would like to thank Ruben for his contribution to the club and wishes him well for the future. Darren Fletcher will take charge of the team against Burnley on Wednesday."

The decision comes after United were held to a 1-1 draw by Leeds at Elland Road on Sunday. In his post-match comments, the 40-year-old alluded to internal issues, stressing that he viewed himself as United's "manager" rather than merely a "coach".

"It's going to be like this for 18 months or when the board decide to change," Amorim said. "That was my point, I want to finish with that. I'm not going to quit. I will do my job until another guy is coming here to replace me."

headline: Ruben Amorim already has next job lined up after meeting with club chief candidate
body: Former Benfica star Nuno Gomes met with Ruben Amorim after the Manchester derby in September and believes Amorim will one day take charge of the Lisbon club. Amorim has been sacked by Manchester United with the club in sixth place in the Premier League, with the move confirmed on Monday morning.

At the time of the meeting, Benfica's manager Bruno Lage found himself days away from the sack. Lage would depart just days after United lost 3-0 to Manchester City, with Jose Mourinho taking his place in the dugout.

Amorim wasn't the only Premier League figure who met with Gomes, a candidate for Benfica's vice presidency and former Portugal international. Manchester City sporting director Hugo Viana was also in attendance, with Gomes sharing more details of the meeting in the autumn.

"I am friends with Ruben Amorim and Hugo Viana," Gomes told Now (via A Bola). "We took advantage of this match and the fact that we were going to meet with Pedro Ferreira to get to know people from Manchester City and Manchester United, to understand how those clubs operate. I had dinner with Hugo Viana and Ruben Amorim, just the three of us."

Gomes stressed at the time that there had been no formal invitation for Amorim to take over at Benfica at the time, with the club recognising he was very much United's man at the time. However, he caught Gomes' eye long before winning his two league titles as manager of Benfica's rivals Sporting CP.

During a campaign event for presidential candidate Noronha Lopes in September, Gomes said he was certain Amorim would take over at Benfica "one day," and reiterated those feelings in his Now interview.

"I am convinced that Ruben Amorim will one day be Benfica's coach. It didn't happen sooner because, after a few meetings, Amorim decided not to accept those conditions while he was at Casa Pia. I was the one who recommended him at the time," Gomes said of the 40-year-old, who also won three league titles as a player at Estadio da Luz and turned down an opportunity to take charge of Benfica's B team.

"Ruben Amorim is a person with very strong convictions. We know how he communicates, works and prepares his teams. When he was at Sporting, we all realised that Amorim is stubborn. At the end of last season, he was in a different situation than he is now at United. I don’t know, but it may have crossed his mind to abandon a project that was difficult to bring to fruition.

"He may have gone through phases where he was more discouraged and had thoughts of slamming the door and leaving. Then, suddenly, he wakes up with the confidence that he will get the team playing well."

Lage was sacked by Benfica in September after a Champions League loss to Qarabag, but things have eventually picked up under Mourinho. They're just one point shy of a place in the Champions League play-off round and just three adrift of second-placed Sporting in the league.

Amorim will now have a decision to make on his return after United brought his tenure to an end after less than 14 months. As for the Premier League club themselves, Darren Fletcher will take temporary charge against Burnley in midweek.

body: Manchester United have been told they must pay a staggering compensation clause if they want to make Eddie Howe their new manager.

Ruben Amorim was sensationally sacked as head coach at Old Trafford on Monday after his extraordinary rant following the draw at Leeds. Amorim sent a blunt message to the United board in his post-match press conference and has been dismissed the following day.

United have taken immediate action after the 1-1 draw at Elland Road, sacking Amorim after 14 months in charge. Former United midfielder Darren Fletcher, who is currently the under-18s coach, will take charge of the team for their Premier League game against Burnley on Wednesday night.

Attention has already swiftly turned to who could replace Amorim. Crystal Palace boss Oliver Glasner emerged as the early favourite with bookmakers, while former England boss Gareth Southgate was 5/1 in the early betting.

Howe, the Newcastle United manager, has been linked with the job in the past and is understood to have admirers still at Old Trafford. Newcastle, however, have moved to protect themselves in case of a move for the 48-year-old.

With Howe believed to be earning approximately £6m annually and having a minimum of three years remaining on his existing contract, any potential suitor would need to fork out a massive eight-figure sum to secure his release. This doesn't even factor in the substantial cost required to tempt away Howe's trusted backroom staff including Jason Tindall, Steve Purchess and Simon Weatherstone.
When Amorim's role came under scrutiny back in October, Chronicle Live questioned Howe about his dedication to the Tyneside club.

"I'm all in (at Newcastle)," Howe declared when quizzed about connections to the Manchester United position in October . "My commitment here is 100% here and always has been. My family is still here, and we are fighting every day to make a success of what we are doing.
"The season ahead could be a wonderful thing, and that is what we are trying to focus on, trying to make a success of the games we have coming up."

Mirror Sport believes that Newcastle received no formal approach from Chelsea regarding Howe, whilst Liam Rosenior prepares to assume control of the Blues following his arrival from partner club Strasbourg. Magpies chiefs will also fight tooth and nail to keep the manager at St James' Park.
Sporting director Ross Wilson said: "We have got an outstanding manager here, and from past experience, I'd certainly rather have one that other people might like rather than one that nobody likes."
Howe had been touted for the England position in 2024 before Thomas Tuchel got the nod. The FA didn't pursue their interest despite widespread speculation following Gareth Southgate's departure.

Reports from Germany suggest that Tuchel will step down from the England role after the World Cup, irrespective of how things pan out in the US. Whether Howe's name enters the frame for the international position at Wembley once more is yet to be determined.
For the time being though, the head coach sees his future firmly planted in the dugout on Tyneside. Consecutive victories have silenced doubters, with Howe describing the coming weeks as crucial.

Newcastle's destiny in both the Carabao Cup and FA Cup will be determined whilst they face their final two Champions League group stage fixtures against PSV Eindhoven and Paris St-Germain, hoping to secure either direct qualification or a play-off spot come spring.
Club owners PIF are eager to see Newcastle earn Champions League qualification through the Premier League once more following last term's fifth-place finish.

headline: Rio Ferdinand saw Ruben Amorim sack coming after Man Utd training ground revelation
body: Manchester United legend Rio Ferdinand says he is not surprised by the club's decision to sack Ruben Amorim given the Portuguese's record. He also revealed that a recent visit to the training ground gave him the impression that the manager's days were numbered.

The Red Devils confirmed on Monday morning that they had decided to part ways with the 40-year-old, despite a noticeable improvement in their performances at Old Trafford. The club issued a statement saying: "Ruben Amorim has departed his role as Head Coach of Manchester United.

"Ruben was appointed in November 2024 and led the team to a UEFA Europa League Final in Bilbao in May. With Manchester United currently sixth in the Premier League, the club's leadership has reluctantly decided that it is the right time for a change.

"This will give the team the best chance of achieving the highest possible Premier League finish. The club would like to thank Ruben for his contribution to the club and wishes him well for the future. Darren Fletcher will take charge of the team against Burnley on Wednesday.

In response to the news, Ferdinand explained that while he was slightly caught unaware by the timing, Amorim's record speaks for itself. Speaking on his Rio Ferdinand Presents YouTube channel, he said: "They have sacked him, they have sacked him!"
He added: "I didn't anticipate this when I woke up this morning that Ruben Amorim would be getting the sack. He was not in the four or five managers I thought would be getting the sack next.

"I am surprised but when you look at his record, in black and white, I'm not surprised. I think that has been definitive and the reason it's been so sharp overnight [speaking out]. Two managers have spoken out against the hierarchy now and been sacked immediately. But his record is the worst of any United manager since Sir Alex Ferguson."

Ferdinand highlighted recent training ground visit sparked concerns that the head coach's time at Old Trafford was drawing to a close. He added: "I saw his last two press conferences and was thinking something isn't right here.

"This guy's best trait and one of the most likeable things about him has been his ability to be quite punchy and upbeat in his press conferences. He had quite a jovial way about himself. The last two he did looked depressing. I didn't say it because I get the ability to go into the training ground and see people and whatnot at times.

"The last time I went there to interview Bruno [Fernandes], I saw the manager and we had a little chat for five or 10 minutes. He's [usually] warm, he spends time with you, he's an open book. When I went there the last time, I noticed immediately that there was a coldness about him. There was a real difference to what I'd seen before.

"Now I look back with hindsight, things were starting to cook before Christmas. This isn't just an overnight thing, I don't think, in terms of his dialogue with the hierarchy and the way he's been feeling about things. I felt this coldness that we've seen in the last two press conferences. I saw it in him.

"The training ground felt good and the vibe around the players. But he just felt a little bit distant. When I saw him last time he was a very different human being. I was thinking it was the wear and tear of a long, hard season and the pressure was getting to him a little bit, maybe he'd woken up on the wrong side of the bed. But now, looking back, this has been cooking before Christmas. One hundred per cent."
After the match at Elland Road, Amorim said: "I came here to be the manager of Manchester United, not to be the coach of Manchester United. That is clear.

"I know that my name is not [Thomas] Tuchel, it's not [Antonio] Conte, it's not [Jose] Mourinho, but I'm the manager of Manchester United. And it's going to be like this for 18 months or when the board decides to change. I'm not going to quit. I will do my job until another guy is coming here to replace me."

Following Amorim's departure, Fletcher will step up to oversee the first-team for Wednesday's Premier League fixture against Burnley. It remains unclear at this stage whether the club will persist with the U18s boss for the remainder of the campaign, or whether they'll bring in a more seasoned top flight manager.

headline: Oliver Glasner comments on Ruben Amorim and Man Utd change speak volumes
body: Crystal Palace boss Oliver Glasner is one of the Premier League managers being linked with a move to Manchester United after the Old Trafford hierarchy made the decision to sack Ruben Amorim. The Austrian's comments earlier on this season suggested that United had turned a corner under the guidance of the Portuguese head coach - but his departure now says otherwise.

United endured a torrid calendar year of 2025, finishing the season in 15th position, claiming just 42 points in the Premier League, winning nine games - their worst return in the competition's history. However, this term, they've claimed 31 points from 20 games and are knocking on the door of the European places.

Things had certainly improved in terms of points return, but performances have been poor with United struggling to adapt to Amorim's 3-4-3 system. A draw with relegation strugglers Wolves and a point at Elland Road last weekend saw Amorim explode in his post-match press conference taking aim at the club's hierarchy and former player Gary Neville.
United released a statement confirming the decision to sack the Portuguese coach, making it clear they want to finish the season as high as possible.

Glasner, who has won the FA Cup and Community Shield in recent months with the Eagles, is among those to be linked with the vacant managerial position and plays a similar system to outgoing boss Amorim.
Speaking earlier this season about United's system under the Portuguese head coach, Glasner defended Amorim pointing to the team's underlying numbers.
"It's really funny talking about the 3-4-3 system, and I think United have the highest xG in the Premier League for scoring goals," Glasner said back in November.
"Their team has changed. Especially in attack. They needed more goals and invested £200m - buying three players up front.
"Also, now they have players who can play very intense like [Bryan] Mbeumo. For me, that's impressive to see. We compared it [their last meeting] to where they are now.
"I think their work-rate is much higher than it was last year and then they get the reward."

Glasner could be a ready-made replacement for Amorim, while his future at Selhurst Park is also up in the air with his contract set to expire this summer. The Austrian yet to pen a new deal with the Eagles and may, in turn, be the answer to United's woes.
"We're playing the same system," Glasner said earlier this season when explaining the benefits of lining up in a 3-4-3.
"So it looks like it's a good attacking system. Also, as we show it, you can have a good defensive structure with it.
"It's all about what you do with the system and how fluid you are in attack and how creative you are."

The subsequent month, whilst not explicitly suggesting resignation, he recognised the decline since taking over from Erik ten Hag in the technical area. "In ten games in the Premier League, we won two," he acknowledged following a loss to Brighton.
"Imagine what this is for a fan of Manchester United. Imagine what this is for me. We are getting a new coach that is losing more than the last coach. I have full knowledge of that.

"We are being the worst team maybe in the history of Manchester United. I know that you want headlines, but I'm saying that because we have to acknowledge that and to change that. Here you go, your headlines."

A solid Europa League run took United within 90 minutes of a trophy in Amorim's first season, and victory in the final could have compensated for domestic woes. However, when United were defeated by Spurs in Bilbao, the manager said he was willing to walk away the very next day if that's what the board desired.

"In this moment, I am not going to be here defending myself, [it] is not my style," he said. "I cannot do it, is really hard for me. So I have nothing to show to the fans to say I am going to improve because of this, I had these problems, I will not do nothing.

"In this moment, it's a little bit of faith. So let's see. Like I said before, coming here before in the flash, I am always open. If the board and fans feel that I'm not the right guy, I will go the next day without any conversation about compensation.
"But I will not quit again. I am really confident in my job and, as you can see, I will not change nothing in the way I do things."

United splashed out over the summer, spending more than £200m on Benjamin Sesko, Matheus Cunha, Bryan Mbeumo and Senne Lammens. However, just weeks into the new season, he was once again hinting at a change in the United dugout after a dismal Carabao Cup defeat to Grimsby Town.
"We played badly for 30 minutes against Fulham. And then that kind of performance, I was really disappointed with everything," Amorim said. "But now it's a new game and I'm focused on the next one.

"If you are in one way, if you have this kind of behaviour, you have to understand that you have things that is good on that type of behaviour, that you have the other side of the coin. So I understand that.

"And again, sometimes I want to quit, sometimes I want to be here for 20 years, sometimes I love to be with my players, sometimes I don't want to be with them. So, again, I need to improve on that. It's going to be hard. But now I'm good with the next one."
He made no apologies for his feelings, stating: "I'm going to say that sometimes I hate my players, sometimes I love my players, sometimes I want to defend my players.

"I think this is my way of doing things and I'm going to be like that. And I felt that in that moment I was so frustrated and [annoyed]. And I know, again, that you have a lot of experienced people talking about the way I should perform with the media, to be more constant, to be more calm. I'm not going to be like that.
"So I'm trying to accept that and I'm going to be who I am. That's why I have the passion that I have."

Amorim's recent remarks have elicited a reaction from Gary Neville, who has observed a shift in the Portuguese manager's attitude of late. "Something has happened in the last week which means that Amorim is starting to unleash a little bit," the former United captain said on the Gary Neville podcast.
"It looks to me that he is not happy with something in the hierarchy. Obviously something is annoying him - he's obviously not feeling the support. He's obviously letting go.
"When you say that you came to the club as a manager, I thought he was appointed as the head coach and quite clearly appointed to coach the team."
It was clear during Amorim's brief tenure that he was not afraid to risk his position. However, the post-Leeds comments proved to be one challenge too many.

headline: Man Utd make instant decision on Ruben Amorim replacement after SACKING manager
body: Manchester United are expected to wait until the summer to appoint a permanent replacement for Ruben Amorim after the club made the decision to SACK him on Monday morning.

Former United midfielder Darren Fletcher is set to take over on an interim basis, with his first game coming in the trip to Burnley on Wednesday. According to The Athletic, the Red Devils are then 'likely' to wait until the end of the season to appoint a permanent successor for Amorim.

The decision to axe Amorim, 40, has been driven by the club's leadership team, including chief executive Omar Berrada and director of football Jason Wilcox, after a breakdown in relationship behind the scenes.
A club statement read: "Ruben Amorim has departed his role as Head Coach of Manchester United. Ruben was appointed in November 2024 and led the team to a UEFA Europa League Final in Bilbao in May.

"With Manchester United sitting sixth in the Premier League, the club’s leadership has reluctantly made the decision that it is the right time to make a change. This will give the team the best opportunity of the highest possible Premier League finish.
"The club would like to thank Ruben for his contribution to the club and wishes him well for the future.
"Darren Fletcher will take charge of the team against Burnley on Wednesday."
Speaking after Sunday's draw at Leeds, Amorim hinted that there is tension with those working alongside him, making it evident he views himself as the "manager" and not the "coach" at United.

"It's going to be like this for 18 months or when the board decide to change," Amorim added. "That was my point, I want to finish with that. I’m not going to quit. I will do my job until another guy is coming here to replace me."
Amorim was appointed as Erik ten Hag's permanent replacement at United in November 2024 after Ruud van Nistelrooy enjoyed a successful four-game reign as interim head coach.
The former Sporting CP boss signed a two-and-a-half year deal at Old Trafford and made a fast start to life at the Red Devils, winning two of his opening three matches in charge.

However, United's form ebbed and flowed from that point on, with the Red Devils progressing in the Europa League but faltering in the Premier League. Indeed, Amorim's side dropped into the bottom half in the top flight and ended up finishing 15th - their lowest-ever finish in 50 years.

But, after United reached the Europa League final, Amorim kept his job and was backed in the summer with the club's board spending more than £200million on new players. Matheus Cunha, Bryan Mbeumo and Benjamin Sesko were the three high-profile players that arrived through the doors.
Although United's Premier League form has improved this season, winning eight and drawing seven of their 20 top-flight fixtures, it hasn't been enough for Amorim to keep his position.

headline: Wilcox row, public criticism and the game that cost him - Inside Ruben Amorim sacking at Man United
body: It was in October that Sir Jim Ratcliffe said he wanted to give Ruben Amorim three years to prove he is a "great coach". In the end, he didn't even get another three months. The man appointed as Manchester United's first head coach was sacked less than 19 hours after demanding to be the manager instead.

What happened at Leeds looks to have been the final straw but conflict has been building for weeks, if not months. Amorim entered his press conference on Friday with a face like thunder and that stemmed from a meeting with director of football Jason Wilcox earlier that day in which there was a clash between the pair.

United's football structure had expected Amorim to adapt from his 3-4-2-1 system as the players became more settled but officials were starting to sense that the Portuguese head coach was never going to do that. In Friday's meeting, Amorim again reacted angrily when his system was raised.
Amorim then poured fuel on the fire by refusing to answer questions as to why he had recently said he wouldn't get the "time or money" to play a "perfect 3-4-3".

But United never promised him the cash to rebuild the squad in his image. When Amorim was approached to take over in November last year, it was agreed he would play his system at the start, with the team seen to be lacking a structure under former boss Erik ten Hag.

The end of the Dutchman's reign had been characterised by end-to-end games with no control and the board felt Amorim's set-up could alleviate some of those issues. But it was agreed from the outset that he would adapt once he had his feet under the table.

By Friday evening, club bosses had come to the conclusion he was never going to do so and felt they had no option but to make a change, with some fearing a slide down the table given the level of performances.

It wasn't solely about Amorim moving from a back five to a back four, but more about the lack of an attacking evolution under the 40-year-old. His style of play has been passive and bland, and the draw with Wolves between Christmas and New Year went down particularly badly with the hierarchy at Old Trafford.

Supporters demanded more attacking intent within that game but with the scores level Amorim replaced Ayden Heaven with Leny Yoro. It was the kind of negative substitution that came to define his reign.

The club had also been unimpressed with some of Amorim's comments in his media dealings. The criticisms of the academy and namechecking Harry Amass and Chido Obi went down particularly badly, but first-team players weren't immune either.
There was disappointment internally at some veiled criticism of Benjamin Sesko earlier in the season, as well as the reference to the anxiety felt when Patrick Dorgu had the ball back in November.

Those issues contributed to the decision to sack Amorim on Monday morning, with Wilcox and chief executive Omar Berrada delivering the news personally. Although club chiefs have denied talk of a rift, it is clear there was conflict and this was a stunning breakdown in relations that left United's hierarchy with little choice but to axe a man they have all staked their reputations on in one way or another.

Even when Ratcliffe made those comments in October, tensions were beginning to creep into working relationships at Carrington. Faith had ebbed away in Amorim's back three system and some of his emotional outbursts, particularly after games, weren't seen as being helpful.

For Amorim's part, he was starting to show signs of frustration at working in a collaborative structure that didn't give him the power he craved. A £230million summer spending spree focused on players who could fit a back three or a back four, rather than signing specialists for the very particular roles in his system.

If there was tension around transfers, that went both ways. Kobbie Mainoo has become a sticking point between Amorim and the structure around him. United were loath to lose another academy graduate, especially a player seen as one of the best to emerge at the club in recent years.

But Amorim has made it clear he doesn't see Mainoo fitting into his 3-4-2-1 shape. He was tried as a No.10 last season, but the summer spending spree on attackers left him well down the pecking order there. The head coach harboured doubts about Mainoo's defensive work, particularly off the ball, and was reluctant to play him as one of the two deeper midfielders.

This left United in a bind. Mainoo wanted to sign for Napoli on loan on deadline day but there was not enough time to bring in a replacement. United officials were also conscious of the optics of letting him go. But Amorim refused to hand him opportunities and Mainoo hasn't started a single Premier League game this season.

The 20-year-old won't mourn the departure of his head coach and he looks certain to stay at Old Trafford now, rather than seek a temporary departure this month. He might also find chances easier to come by in a three-man midfield, a tactical approach Amorim refused to get on board with.

There were concerns last season that his unique system wasn't translating to the Premier League and was too predictable. Those became sharper internally after the draw with Fulham earlier this season, when director of recruitment Christopher Vivell shared comments from Fulham boss Marco Silva that detailed how easy it was to prepare to face Amorim's United.

When Rob Edwards made similar comments after the draw with Wolves last week, it set alarm bells ringing once again, particularly as that return to a back three came after Amorim had briefly considered a peace accord with Wilcox and co.

His bosses had urged him to be more tactically adaptable and he duly played 4-3-3 against Newcastle on Boxing Day. It was a game from which conclusions were hard to draw, with United looking good in the first half and then hanging on in the second.

Amorim had seen enough, however. He abandoned the flirtation with changing his system and decided if he was going down, it would be on his own sword. He had had enough of the interference from above and stuck to his own principles, with that tactical clash leading to some of the emotion he has shown in recent weeks.

There was also conflict over transfers. United has sought to introduce a more integrated approach to recruitment since the Ineos takeover, but it has left Amorim unable to secure the players he really wanted. There was some tension of the identity of the striker signed in the summer, with United opting to move for Sesko, despite having a similar profile to Rasmus Hojlund.
Those signings were players who United felt could play in a number of roles, but Amorim was sticking to his tactical guns rather than adapting as had been agreed.
When he was asked about recruitment recently, he hinted that he and Wilcox didn't always agree but that every club should listen to the manager, because they know the style of play.
Ultimately, Amorim's style of play wasn't winning anyone over at United, and his stubbornness eventually proved too much.

headline: MARSHALL: Manchester United have sacked Ruben Amorim after power struggle claim and new demands
body: Manchester United insist Ruben Amorim was sacked due to a lack of progress on the pitch and have denied there was a power struggle going on at Old Trafford, despite Amorim bringing those tensions into the open over the last week.

Amorim was sacked on Monday morning, less than 19 hours after a remarkable press conference at Elland Road in which he demanded more power and told director of football Jason Wilcox to "do his job". Tensions between Amorim and members of the football leadership team, including Wilcox and director of recruitment Christopher Vivell, have become public in recent weeks and Amorim laid them bare at Elland Road.

His stunning remarks left nobody in any doubt that were issues behind the scenes at Old Trafford. Amorim's job came under immediate scrutiny and after what was essentially a 'back me or sack me' plea, his 63-game reign was brought to an end on Monday.

But United sources insist that the decision was made solely on results and denied there had been any power struggles or that Amorim had laid down an ultimatum demanding more power. They insist the 40-year-old maintained the 'unwavering support' of everyone within the club but there hadn't been enough progress for him to continue in the role.

Amorim had been frustrated at being told there was no money to spend in January and was keen to add a midfielder to his squad, with United initially showing interest in attacker Antoine Semenyo before tightening the purse strings.

The decision was made to sign three attacking players last summer, in Bryan Mbeumo, Matheus Cunha and Benjamin Sesko, as well as goalkeeper Senne Lammens, and United insist Amorim was on board with that recruitment plan and happy with the decision to strengthen the attack over the midfield.

In his press conference after the Leeds draw, Amorim had demanded to be the manager at United rather than the coach, even though his job title since his appointment in November 2024 was head coach. United have no plans to change that structure and their next appointment is likely to have to accept the same job title.

United sources point out that the £250million spent since Amorim's arrival made the club one of the highest spenders in the Premier League in that time. Although the team have shown signs of improvement this season and sit sixth in the Premier League, the decision has been made to axe Amorim to give the squad a better chance of qualifying for the Champions League next season.

Manchester United have sacked Ruben Amorim as head coach after a breakdown in relations with club bosses was laid bare in a remarkable press conference after the draw with Leeds.
Amorim's strained relationship with director of football Jason Wilcox has been brought into the open by the 40-year-old in recent weeks and his outburst on Sunday has proved to be the final straw.
The Portuguese was informed on Monday morning that he was being sacked and he leaves the club with immediate affect. He departs with a record of just 24 wins in 63 games.

headline: Rio Ferdinand sends clear Oliver Glasner message over Man United links after Ruben Amorim sack
body: Rio Ferdinand has claimed he would "put all my money on" Oliver Glasner not being appointed as Ruben Amorim's replacement at Manchester United.
Crystal Palace manager Glasner, 51, has emerged as a contender to succeed Amorim at Old Trafford after the club decided to sack the Portuguese head coach on Monday morning.

Glasner has done a stellar job since joining Palace in February 2024, guiding them to FA Cup glory at the end of last season and then the Community Shield at the start of this campaign. During his time in south London, the ex-Wolfsburg and Eintracht Frankfurt boss has won 41 and drawn 28 of his 93 matches in charge.

With United deciding to axe Amorim, Glasner has been linked with becoming the next United head coach. However, Ferdinand doesn't see the Reds appointing Glasner, due to the fact he uses a three-at-the-back formation.

"No way," ex-United defender Ferdinand said on Rio Ferdinand Presents when asked about the possibility of Glasner taking over. "There's no way, I don't think. I would be so surprised if Glasner gets an opportunity to be Man United manager given that he plays three-at-the-back.
"Based on how this team has performed and the narrative that has been surrounding the team since Amorim has been here: I would put all my money on it that he doesn't get that job."

Amorim had faced pressure for sticking with his three-at-the-back system despite performances and results not improving at the race some were hoping for. Indeed, after using his tried-and-trusted 3-4-2-1 formation for most of last Tuesday's 1-1 draw against rock bottom Wolves, Amorim was scrutinised even more.

Glasner, meanwhile, has enjoyed success with his 3-4-3 shape at Palace. Marc Guehi, Maxence Lacroix and Chris Richards are the three that have typically provided a solid foundation at the back, with Daniel Munoz and Tyrick Mitchell giving width as the two wing-backs. Adam Wharton and one of Will Hughes or Jefferson Lerma have been used as the midfield two, followed by a dynamic front three including Jean-Philippe Mateta.

It's a system that has worked for Glasner, with Palace riding the crest of a wave in their first-ever European campaign and sitting comfortable in mid-table in the Premier League. Although the Eagles have lost four of their last five top-flight matches, they still sit just four points behind fifth-place Chelsea in the table.

As for United, Darren Fletcher is set to take charge on an interim basis for Wednesday's trip to Burnley. They will be looking to return to winning ways after back-to-back draws against Wolves and Leeds United.

headline: MARSHALL: One person is coming of Ruben Amorim debacle with credit - and he's already left Man United
body: Dan Ashworth would have known the end was coming at Manchester United when he was marched through the press conference room soon after the defeat to Nottingham Forest in December 2024. This was a public sacking for a figure who had gone from hero to zero in five months in the eyes of Sir Jim Ratcliffe.

Ashworth was the man Ratcliffe called "one of the best sporting directors in the world" during protracted negotiations with Newcastle to lure him to Old Trafford. However, within months, relations had soured. It reflected poorly on Ratcliffe at the time and now, with the dismissal of Ruben Amorim, the manager over whom Ashworth had so many reservations, even worse.

Ratcliffe could have picked up the phone to anyone in the game and been told Ashworth was a structures guy, not the kind of sporting director who would hand over a list of the five most highly rated 30-something coaches in Europe. He was a sensible appointment for a club that needed reshaping. But his caution over the appointment of Amorim ultimately did for him.

Ashworth could see the problems coming of parachuting in a head coach mid-season who had a distinctive playing style. This wasn't a squad built for Amorim's 3-4-2-1 and neither did United have the cash to transform it.

It was a sensible, pragmatic, common-sense approach, but didn't fit with the bravado and excitement of everyone else involved. Amorim was the shiny new toy, the up-and-coming coach who had built an excellent reputation at Sporting and when he guided his old club to a 4-1 win against Manchester City in November 2024, Old Trafford had fallen head over heels.

In hindsight, now that the Portuguese has been unceremoniously sent packing after just 14 months at the helm, the concerns Ashworth highlighted were correct. Amorim might still be an excellent coach (or manager), and with the right players, his system might be a success somewhere. But these weren't conditions he was ever likely to encounter at United and it's been proven.

Instead, he played his system without the tools to do and his team became too predictable as a result. Most of the best managers in the game have a fairly distinctive style of play, but it is often unstoppable because they have the players to execute it. Not at Old Trafford. Not for Amorim.
When his bosses were telling him to change the system and that there was no money, it was hard to see how he would ever survive and create a successful team. That chance is now gone.

Director of football Jason Wilcox and chief executive Omar Berrada are damaged by the episode, their reputations at the club linked to Amorim's appointment. This was their big call and it has gone horribly wrong.

It will take some explaining away when there was at least one senior figure in the building sounding the alarm bells. They ignored that warning and pressed ahead anyway. The surprise is the nature of the unravelling. less than 14 months on, not that it happened.
So now, does Ratcliffe trust Wilcox and Berrada to get the next appointment right? Ratcliffe himself has hitched himself to the success of a head coach he likes.

The 73-year-old was desperate for his first appointment to be the right one, but that has not happened. Now, the past 14 months feel like a waste. United are no further on than when Erik ten Hag was sacked - and the Dutchman won trophies, in fairness to him.

Ashworth might have advocated an appointment considered safer, maybe even a little more boring. He would have been panned for pushing Gareth Southgate's credentials and Thomas Frank has struggled with the step up from Brentford to Tottenham. But in pointing out the pitfalls of going for Amorim, he could see what was likely to happen.

headline: Oliver Glasner's true feelings on Ruben Amorim and Man United after sack decision
body: Crystal Palace manager Oliver Glasner is among those being touted for a move to Manchester United following the dismissal of Ruben Amorim by Old Trafford bosses. Earlier this season, the Austrian's remarks suggested that United had made progress under the Portuguese coach's leadership, but his departure tells a different story.

United had a dismal 2025, ending the season in 15th place with a mere 42 points in the Premier League and only nine victories - their worst performance in the competition's history. This season they've amassed 31 points from 20 matches and sit in sixth place.

While there has been an improvement in terms of points gained, the team's performances have been lacklustre as they struggled to adapt to Amorim's 3-4-3 formation. A draw against relegation-threatened Wolves and a point at Elland Road last weekend led to a fiery post-match press conference from Amorim, where he criticised the club's management and former player Gary Neville.
United issued a statement confirming Amorim's sacking, emphasising their ambition to finish the season as high up the table as possible.

Glasner, who recently led the Eagles to FA Cup and Community Shield victories, is one of the names linked with the now vacant managerial role at United, and his tactical approach aligns closely with that of the now-departed Amorim.
Speaking earlier this season about United's approach under the Portuguese manager, Glasner defended Amorim by highlighting the team's statistical performance.
"It's really funny talking about the 3-4-3 system, and I think United have the highest xG in the Premier League for scoring goals," Glasner said back in November.
"Their team has changed. Especially in attack. They needed more goals and invested £200m - buying three players up front.
"Also, now they have players who can play very intense like [Bryan] Mbeumo. For me, that's impressive to see. We compared it [their last meeting] to where they are now.
"I think their work-rate is much higher than it was last year and then they get the reward."

Glasner could represent an immediate solution to replace Amorim, whilst his own situation at Selhurst Park remains uncertain with his contract due to run out this summer. The Austrian is yet to sign fresh terms with the Eagles and might prove to be the solution to United's difficulties.
"We're playing the same system," Glasner said earlier this season when explaining the benefits of lining up in a 3-4-3.
"So it looks like it's a good attacking system. Also, as we show it, you can have a good defensive structure with it.
"It's all about what you do with the system and how fluid you are in attack and how creative you are."

headline: Sir Jim Ratcliffe has already named manager he admires after Ruben Amorim Man United sack
body: After sacking Ruben Amorim, Sir Jim Ratcliffe has a big decision to make.

Manchester United have shown flashes of promise this season, but a run of disappointing results - coupled with a breakdown in relations between manager and ownership - led to the axe falling on the Portuguese coach after just 14 months in charge.
Attention now turns to Amorim's successor. While the Red Devils will have no shortage of candidates, one manager Ratcliffe has previously admitted admiring may prove far harder to persuade.

That man is Jurgen Klopp, who famously led Liverpool to both Premier League and Champions League glory. Ratcliffe has waxed lyrical about the German in the past, suggesting that Klopp could well be a dream target of his.

"Klopp has this ability to drive his players to a frenzy," he said back in March 2024, shortly after taking over footballing operations at Old Trafford. "Total commitment on the pitch. And, you know, that's one of the things a good coach can do."
Klopp is currently Head of Global Soccer at Red Bull, having joined the company shortly after leaving Liverpool at the end of the 2023/24 season.
He has previously insisted that his time at Liverpool would be his last in management. Combined with the fierce rivalry between the two clubs, a move to Old Trafford appears supremely unlikely.

Instead, the Red Devils will have to turn their attention to other, more realistic targets. Crystal Palace boss Oliver Glasner is thought to be among the favourites for the role, along with former England head coach Gareth Southgate - another man long admired by Ratcliffe.

Bournemouth's Andoni Iraola, Aston Villa's Unai Emery and former United defender Laurent Blanc are also being linked. For now, however, U-18s coach Darren Fletcher will take charge on an interim basis until a permanent successor is named.
In a statement on Monday morning, United confirmed Amorim's departure. "Ruben Amorim has departed his role as Head Coach of Manchester United," the statement read.

"Ruben was appointed in November 2024 and led the team to a UEFA Europa League Final in Bilbao in May. With Manchester United sitting sixth in the Premier League, the club's leadership has reluctantly made the decision that it is the right time to make a change.

"This will give the team the best opportunity of the highest possible Premier League finish. The club would like to thank Ruben for his contribution to the club and wishes him well for the future. Darren Fletcher will take charge of the team against Burnley on Wednesday."

Amorim's departure comes in the wake of United's 1-1 draw with Leeds at Elland Road on Sunday. Speaking after the game, the 40-year-old hinted at tensions behind the scenes, insisting he considered himself "manager" of United, rather than simply "coach".

"It's going to be like this for 18 months or when the board decide to change," Amorim said. "That was my point, I want to finish with that. I'm not going to quit. I will do my job until another guy is coming here to replace me."

headline: Manchester United's next five fixtures as Ruben Amorim replacement confirmed
body: Manchester United have sacked Ruben Amorim. In a statement released on Monday morning, the Old Trafford club confirmed that the Portuguese, who took charge in November 2024, has left his role with immediate effect.

It was also confirmed in the statement that Darren Fletcher will take charge of Wednesday’s Premier League game against Burnley. United will head to Turf Moor sixth in the top-flight after a 1-1 draw at Leeds United yesterday afternoon.
After the game against the Clarets, the Reds take a break from the Premier League when they welcome Brighton & Hove Albion to Old Trafford in the FA Cup on Sunday.
United then face Manchester City at Old Trafford six days later before traveling to the capital to take on Arsenal at the Emirates Stadium on Sunday, January 25.
The Reds then kick-off February with a home game against Fulham. Following United’s 1-1 draw with Leeds on Sunday, Amorim delivered an explosive press conference in which he made a number of remarks.
He insisted he is the manager, not the coach of United, and challenged his sporting director and scouting department “to do their job”.
Amorim also hinted he could leave when his current deal runs out in 18 months time - if he wasn't sacked before then.

He said: “Guys, to stop with that — and I noticed that you receive selective information about everything — I came here to be the manager of Manchester United, not to be the coach of Manchester United.
“That is clear. I know that my name is not Tuchel, it’s not Conte, it’s not Mourinho, but I’m the manager of Manchester United.

“It’s going to be like this for 18 months, or when the board decides to change. That was my point. I want to finish with that. I’m not going to quit. I will do my job until another guy comes here to replace me.”
Before he added: “I just want to say that I’m going to be the manager of this team, not just the coach.
“I was really clear on that. And that is going to finish in 18 months. And then everyone is going to move on. That was the deal. That is my job, not to be a coach.
“If people cannot handle the Gary Nevilles and the criticism of everything, we need to change the club.
“Every department, the scouting department, the sports director, needs to do their job. I will do mine for 18 months and then we move on.”

headline: Gareth Southgate 'has two demands' if Manchester United replace Ruben Amorim with him
body: Manchester United have reportedly been informed that Gareth Southgate would require 'time' and 'patience' from the club if he were to replace Ruben Amorim. The Reds are on the hunt for their seventh permanent manager since Sir Alex Ferguson's retirement in 2013, following the dismissal of Amorim on Monday.

Doubts over Amorim's future as United boss emerged after Sunday's 1-1 draw at Leeds with the Portuguese hinting at a possible departure when his contract expires in 18 months. Despite officially being appointed as head coach by Ineos in November 2024, the former Sporting man insisted on being referred to as the manager at Old Trafford.

Ineos have now decided to terminate the Amorim project, sacking him after a 14-month stint at M16. The club released a statement confirming his dismissal, expressing optimism that this change will enhance their Premier League performance this season, with European football still very much within reach.
As early as October last year - while Amorim was still at the helm - it was reported that former England manager Southgate was contemplating whether to vie for the managerial role at Old Trafford.

However, it's been suggested that Southgate may have reservations about accepting the role and would require a four-year commitment to turn things around; a timeframe the board might not be willing to offer him or any other candidate. According to The Sun, insiders have indicated that the lifelong United supporter would need assurances that the club's hierarchy would commit to any long-term objectives.

The report also suggests Southgate is worried the board may expect immediate results, whereas his approach focuses on achieving success gradually over an extended period. The 55-year-old has been unemployed since resigning as England manager after leading the Three Lions to second place at Euro 2024, where they lost 2-1 to Spain in the final.

However, the ex-Crystal Palace, Aston Villa and Middlesbrough player-turned-manager has been linked with a managerial position at United since Sir Jim Ratcliffe acquired a minority stake in the club in February 2024.
Southgate isn't the only manager being considered to replace Amorim. Oliver Glasner, of Palace, and Brighton's Fabian Hurzeler are rumoured favourites for the move to Old Trafford.
Real Madrid legend Zinedine Zidane and Barcelona icon Xavi Hernandez have also been mentioned as potential candidates.

headline: MARSHALL: Manchester United have been handed a January opportunity they can't afford to miss
body: The year ended with a whimper for Manchester United. A 1-1 draw with Wolves on Tuesday night continued a dire recent run at Old Trafford and set alarm bells ringing again about the progress of this team under Ruben Amorim.

Dropping points against a side with 16 defeats and two draws from their first 18 games wasn't a good look. Amorim refused to use the absence of key players to injuries and international call-ups as an excuse, and any team United put out should be capable of beating this Wolves team.

However, it is true that Amorim's resources are currently stretched. The damage done was also eased by other results. Chelsea dropped points at home to Bournemouth, just as United did in December, and then sacked head coach Enzo Maresca on New Year's Day.

Elsewhere on the first day of 2026, Liverpool lumbered to a goalless draw with Leeds at Anfield. Arne Slot's side have picked up better results recently, but they still aren't playing well and are having to grind out results every week.

With the top three of Arsenal, Manchester City and Aston Villa edging clear, it might be that two from three of United, Chelsea and Liverpool will qualify for the Champions League, presuming the Premier League can land that fifth spot once again for next season.

There will be honourable mentions for Sunderland and Everton, who have had excellent first halves of the season, while the league is so congested that only five points separate Chelsea in fifth from Brighton in 14th. A good run of form could propel any number of clubs into the mix.

For United, they would probably have taken this at the halfway stage of the campaign. They are sixth, behind Chelsea only on goal difference and three points shy of Liverpool. Qualification for the Champions League is attainable this season.

The concern is that a woeful run at home might look costly come the end of the season. They have taken three points from home games against Everton, West Ham, Bournemouth and Wolves. The first of those played with 10 men for the best part of 80 minutes and the other three were - and still are - in poor form.

United will have to improve to make the top five, but possibly not by much. Liverpool still look like a flawed team, and Chelsea are unpredictable. The departure of Maresca might change things, but a young and inexperienced squad will be tested in the second half of the campaign.

Amorim's side haven't taken advantage of a kinder fixture list recently and now face Manchester City and Arsenal in January, but having put themselves in a position to achieve what was the primary objective this season, they should consider rolling the dice this month.

Interest in Antoine Semenyo waned when it became clear he wanted to move to Manchester City, but United's willingness to do a deal suggests there is money available to improve the squad. The conditions for a January deal are that the focus remains on long-term targets and adding real quality this month can be difficult to do.

Beefing up numbers to compensate for the lack of depth is also an issue that should ease as the month progresses. Kobbie Mainoo, Mason Mount and Bruno Fernandes should all be back fit soon and Noussair Mazraoui, Amad and Bryan Mbeumo will be back from the Africa Cup of Nations by January 19 at the latest.

But United should be and are alert to opportunities in midfield, with question marks over the futures of several key players. There is also uncertainty as to whether Mainoo will push for a loan move if his chances of first-team football don't improve over the next couple of weeks.

Joshua Zirkzee is also eyeing up a move to Roma. His departure could leave Amorim short of attacking opportunities, with Benjamin Sesko the only natural centre-forward in the squad. Finding a permanent replacement might not be easy, but adding a striker to the squad to offer support and cover for Sesko could be beneficial.

These kinds of January deals might only move the needle ever so slightly; they might only be worth a point or two come the final calculations, but in what is shaping up to be a tight race for places in the top five, that might be all it takes to make them value for money.
At the halfway stage, United have put themselves in the conversation. Now they need to do all they can to finish the job.
